content: "http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,506915,00.html" Britain's nuclear defense headquarters could be under threat from terrorists using Google Earth. Close-up aerial views of the top-secret naval base are on the computer program — available for free over the internet. It even reveals the longitude and latitude of the facility in Faslane, Scotland — home to the U.K.'s Trident-armed nuclear submarine force. And pictures clearly show two vast Vanguard Class submarines — each capable of carrying 16 nuclear missiles. Military experts warn that would make it easy for terrorists to launch accurate mortar or rocket attacks. One told The Sun: "A strike on our nuclear capability would cause untold devastation. Terrorists could have a field day, knowing exactly where to aim strikes to cause the maximum devastation." As well as HM Naval Base Clyde at Faslane, the program also clearly shows the Trident Special Area near Coulport, just 10 miles away, where nuclear warheads are stored. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

title: Google Earth Uncovers British Nuclear Sub Base, Missile Facility

content: Oh for Christ's sake. Anyone that has been to Fastlane or even Holy Loch when the USN was there can take all the photos they want just from the hills surrounding both. Hell, you can even take some shots from the train from Glasgow to Oban.

content: Look up darn near any base on Google Earth. Ex: I looked at Mayport, FL the other day and there was the JFK carrier moored. Most of these photos are dated years back. An attack based on those photos could end up with people with egg on their faces. Heck, come visit my home town of Portsmouth, NH and you'll have no problems seeing the USS New Hampshire (if it's still there) or another sub. It's not like the Pisquataqua River is closed off to the public. Portsmouth Naval Shipyard with USS New Hampshire moored at dock. Don

content: They are old. JFK is gone now. About a year... I heard there is a new cooler function on some of these where you can view things over time. But even with these functions, I don't think it is particularly recent information. However... There are commercial companies out there where you can ring up and they will be a shot for you. And it will be recent.

content: If you think this is bad, go look at the FOB's in Iraq or Balad airbase in Afghanistan via Google Earth. It's all there, but it's meaningless...unless you really do think our enemies will use 2 or 3 year old pictures to attack us. By the way, the reverse is true too. Go to Vietnam and take your time surveying the Vietnamese Air Force base in Danang. Or, take a tour of military bases in Russia or China or India or Japan.
